Arithmetic shift A shift operation that preserves the value of the sign bit (most significant bit). In a right shift, this results in the sign bit being copied into the succeeding bit positions
ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange). A 7-bit character code widely used in computers and communications
A computer language in which the programmer can use mnemonic operation codes, labels, and names to refer to their numerical equivalents
BSC (Binary Synchronous Communications or BISYNC). An older line protocol often used by IBM computers and terminals
Invert; see also one's complement, two's complement
See Disable, but most often applied to interrupts
Endless loop or jump-to-self instruction. An instruction that transfers control to itself, thus executing indefinitely (or until a hardware signal interrupts it
Placing values in storage areas not previously in use, initializing memory or storage
Number system with base 16. The digits are the decimal numbers 0 through 9, followed by the letters A through F
The process of addressing memory and reading an instruction into the CPU for decoding and execution
A signal that temporarily suspends the computer's normal sequence of operations and transfers control to a special routine
See Input/output control block
A computer language in which each statement is translated directly into a single machine language instruction
A computer that has a microprocessor as its central processing unit
A complete central processing unit for a computer constructed from one or a few integrated circuits
Page 0. In 6502 terminology, the lowest 256 addresses in memory
An interface between a CPU and input or output devices that handle data in parallel (more than one bit at a time

note: flag (F) register, status register, and status word.
title: A register that defines the current state of a com puter, often containing various bits indicating internal conditions. Other names for this register include condition code register
Program counter (PC or P register). A register that contains the address of the next instruction to be fetched from memory
An I/O device that can have its mode of operation determined by loading registers under program control
A device that can handle a variety of timing tasks, including the generation of delays, under program control
A memory that can be read but not altered in normal operation

note: It has been partially superseded by RS-449.
title: A standard interface for the transmission of serial digital data, sponsored by the Electronic Industries Association of Washing ton, D.C
SDLC (Synchronous Data Link Control). The successor protocol to BSC for IBM computers and terminals
Standard (or 8,4,2,1) BCD. A BCD representation in which the bit positions have the same weights as in ordinary binary numbers
Halts execution and preserves the status of the task until some future time
A character that is used only to synchronize the transmitter and the receiver
Operating according to an overall timing source or clock, that is, at regular intervals
See Versatile Interface Adapter
A binary-coded decimal format in which each 8-bit byte contains only one decimal digit
